TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr J. Pajcsics , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by Mr PERSON , Deputy ORG - Secretary , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant is a professional hunter . At the relevant time he had a firearms licence ; through his interest in firearms he became acquainted with Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON In early CARDINAL PERSON gave the applicant a hand grenade as a present . In DATE Mr A.D. , an acquaintance of PERSON , met a person called “ PERSON ” in a club . PERSON asked GPE whether he could procure CARDINAL hand grenades for him . GPE promised to look into the matter and obtained the applicant ’s phone number from PERSON He repeatedly called the applicant to ask whether he could help him in procuring the hand grenades . The applicant eventually undertook to hand over to him the grenade he had received as a present . At their meeting PERSON was also present and discussed the price of the grenades with them .

Afterwards , PERSON called the applicant regularly , asking him to procure the CARDINAL grenades . The applicant contacted PERSON and requested CARDINAL hand grenades from him . On DATE the applicant obtained CARDINAL grenades from PERSON On the way home he met DATE and PERSON . They decided to conclude their business DATE . On DATE , instead of PERSON , police officers arrived at the meeting and searched the applicant ’s car . They found CARDINAL hand grenades in it . The applicant was arrested together with GPE

Subsequently , criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant on charges of the abuse of explosives . During the investigation the applicant confessed to the offence . However , he maintained that he had been entrapped by PERSON into committing it .

On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer requested ORG to investigate the matter of police entrapment , having regard to the suspicion that the person called PERSON was an undercover police officer whose identity the Head of ORG refused to reveal . The Prosecutor stated that PERSON might be an undercover police officer who had secretly collected information about the applicant . However , he refused to open an investigation into the matter and took the view that the Head of ORG had proceeded lawfully throughout .
The Budapest XIV / ORG charged the applicant with the abuse of explosives . Subsequently , he was also charged with the abuse of firearms .

During the hearings before ORG the applicant maintained that , although he had committed the offence , he had not had any intention to trade in grenades and only did so because of the incitement by PERSON , an undercover police officer . He claimed that the officer ’s incitement had not been justified , since the police had no good reason to suspect the applicant of any prior involvement in selling hand grenades . He had no criminal record and there was nothing to suggest that he was predisposed to becoming involved in dealing in grenades until approached by PERSON .

On DATE ORG convicted the applicant of the abuse of explosives and firearms , and sentenced him , as a cumulative punishment , to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , suspended for DATE . In reaching its conclusion ORG stressed the fact that the applicant had had no previous criminal record , that time had elapsed and that the applicant had confessed . The court established that a person called PERSON had been involved in the case , but could not be identified . It relied on the testimonies of the accused and CARDINAL witnesses , expert opinions and documentary evidence .

The applicant appealed . He argued that LAW had been violated in that he did not have a fair trial before FAC . He referred to the ORG ’s case - law , in particular the cases of Lüdi v. GPE ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) and PERSON v. GPE ( judgment of DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL-IV ) .
For its part , ORG appealed against the leniency of the sentence imposed on the applicant , having regard to the widespread bomb attacks taking place at the material time .

ORG examined the applicant ’s allegations concerning the fairness of the proceedings . It requested ORG to supply information about the identity of PERSON . It sought to have the police officer in charge of the operation exempted from his duty of confidentiality . The court intended to hear both men as witnesses . In reply to this request , the Head of ORG stated that PERSON was an informer acting on police instructions , pursuant to LAW CARDINAL ( a ) of LAW . He refused to give further information about PERSON or to exempt his handler from his duty of confidentiality .
In these circumstances , ORG was forced to endorse the first - instance court ’s findings of fact . In its judgment of DATE it upheld the applicant ’s conviction and sentence .
ORG held that the applicant and his accomplices would not have committed the offence without the pressure of the undercover police agent . However , it held as follows :

“ The act committed by the defendants is an act which is obviously dangerous for society and which therefore matches the notion of a criminal offence ( section CARDINAL § QUANTITY of LAW ) . Its danger for society can not be questioned even if there was indeed a provocation by the police , that is , if instigation DATE known to or encouraged by the police – took place . ”

The court considered that although the police instigation did not exonerate the applicant , his right to a fair trial was nevertheless infringed , notably in the light of the ORG and LOC cases . It also considered that the fact that the applicant would not have committed the offence , without incitement by PERSON , was a factor to be taken into account when imposing sentence . Consequently , it rejected the prosecution ’s request to increase the applicant ’s sentence , despite its own finding that the offence was particularly dangerous for society , given the frequency of bomb attacks at the time . However , it did not mitigate the applicant ’s sentence as requested by the latter in his appeal .
The court also noted that , in separate proceedings , the applicant had meanwhile been convicted of an abuse of ammunition by ORG on DATE .
Concerning the assessment of the evidence , ORG stated as follows :

“ The findings of fact are based on lawfully obtained evidence , namely the defendants’ admissions , the police report on their apprehension and the information contained in TIME of seizure . The doubt prevailing in the case ( whether or not PERSON instigated the crime ) was assessed in the GPE favour – the court accepted their testimonies in this connection . ”
“ [ ... R]eview proceedings may be initiated ... if ...
( a ) a person was ... convicted ... in breach of the substantive provisions of criminal law ; ... ”
“ ORG may quash the decision reviewed and instruct the lower - instance court ... to resume its proceedings , if :
a ) the second - instance court gave its decision on the merits in breach of the substantive provisions of criminal law referred to under LAW , ... . ”

“ In the hypothesis described under paragraph CARDINAL subparagraph a ) [ of section CARDINAL ] , ORG may itself deliver a decision in accordance with the law , if this will result in the acquittal of the defendant , ... the discontinuation of the proceedings , or the imposition of a less severe punishment . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) A criminal offence is an act perpetrated intentionally or DATE if the law also punishes negligent perpetration – by negligence , which represents a danger for society and for which the law orders the infliction of punishment .
( CARDINAL ) An activity or omission shall be an act dangerous to society if it violates or endangers the constitutional , social or economic order of GPE , or the person or rights of citizens . ”
“ A person , whose act at the time of perpetration represents little danger to society so that even the most lenient punishment ... is unnecessary , shall not be punishable . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any person who , without a licence , prepares , obtains , possesses or transfers to an unauthorised person explosives or blasting - agents or equipment for their use , commits a crime , punishable with imprisonment of DATE . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) Any person who
a ) prepares , obtains , possesses or distributes firearms or ammunition without a licence ,
b ) exceeds the provisions of a licence relating to the preparation , obtaining , possession or trade of firearms or ammunition ,
c ) transfers his licensed firearm or ammunition to a person who has no licence ;
commits a crime , punishable with imprisonment of DATE . ”

“ It is not allowed to deliver a judgment in which the court finds the defendant guilty of CARDINAL of the cumulative offences with which the latter has been charged and imposes a sentence , while discontinues the proceedings in respect of another offence , having regard to its negligible danger to society ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) . ”
